com.schneide.quantity
Class AbstractQuantity

java.lang.Object
  com.schneide.quantity.AbstractQuantity
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbstractAcceleration, AbstractActivity, AbstractAmountOfSubstance, AbstractArea, AbstractCapacity, AbstractCharge, AbstractConcentration, AbstractCurrent, AbstractCurrentDensity, AbstractDensity, AbstractElectricFieldStrength, AbstractElectromagneticInduction, AbstractEnergy, AbstractEnergyDose, AbstractForce, AbstractFrequency, AbstractInductance, AbstractLength, AbstractLuminousIntensity, AbstractMagneticFieldStrength, AbstractPower, AbstractPressure, AbstractResistance, AbstractSpeed, AbstractTemperature, AbstractTime, AbstractVoltage, AbstractVolume, AbstractWeight, CountableQuantity, GradCelsius, GradFahrenheit, Quantity, Sievert
public abstract class AbstractQuantity
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable

The AbstractQuantity is the superclass of all Quantity classes. It contains all the functionality to calculate and transform between quantities. It is tightly coupled with the class CompoundUnit. Together the class AbstractQuantity and CompoundUnit contain the functionality of the framework. Inherited classes bring the functionality to the user in form of specialized quantities.

A Quantity combines a value with a unit. More specific, a Quantity of the library com.schneide.quantity contains 3 members called value, power and compoundUnit which together represent a Quantity in the form of 

 	value * 10^power compoundUnit
See class CompoundUnit for details of the unit part and AtomarSignature for explanation of the term signature to understand how this framework operates.

To get to know all about the use and the architekture of the quantity framework have a look on our Homepage.

Author:
Matthias Kempka, Anja Hauth

equalsWithEpsilon

public boolean equalsWithEpsilon(AbstractQuantity compareQuantity,
                                 double epsilon)
substracts compareQuantity from this and checks wether the result is smaller than epsilon This allows the comparison of two almost-equal quantities which may result due to rounding errors.

Parameters:
compareQuantity - the AbstractQuantity to compare with
epsilon - a double value for the difference allowed between the two AbstractQuantities
Returns:
boolean returns true if this.value - compareQuantity.value > epsilon and no errors occur during substraction.
